bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, August 7, 1942

div1.p: Kean believes that the fever charts mentioned by Hench were probably copies of the originals. He doesn't remember much about his own illness with yellow fever except the headache and backache.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, August 7, 1942
div1.opener:
answered from Ft. Custer 8/16/42
2804 N STREET, N. W.
WASHINGTON, D. C. August 7 1942
My dear Dr. Hench
div1.p:
Your letter of the 1st gave me
great pleasure and I was much
interested in the inclosures and thank
you for sending them- It was very
clever of you to think of writing to
Mrs. Ames about them and very
decent of her to let you have them.
I would think that the fever charts
of Dr. Ames and myself were copies
made, perhaps in the S. G. O., evidently
by the same clerical hand- As you say
original bedside charts would be never
so neat, well written and clean-

The notes of my case were evidently
made by the attendant on duty, who
2
was probably Lambert, but I am
sorry to say that I do not remember
very clearly anything that happened
during my illness except the headache
and the backache, and the wonderful
refreshment of the champagne after
four days of water only- The temp.
& pulse do not look like those of a
very sick man & the only serious symp-
tom I had was hemorrhage from
the gums which caused Stark to
give a bad prognosis- I do not know
if there is any record of the examinations
of the urine, which is of course very
important in yellow fever- My
impression is that there was very
little albumen, tho., in the first five
days, the amount of urine seems
3
to have been rather deficient, being
a total of 2495 c. c. to a fluid intake
of 4743 c c - a daily average of
about a pint of urine to an intake of
a quart of fluid- If the charts of the
experimental cases at Camp Lazear
are as fairly made out as mine &
Ames's are (which are evidently made
by the same person) I would say they
were copies- Are they in the same
hand as mine & Ames'?

Isn't it curious that Ames makes his
a s just like his o s-

I think that Ames's comment on the
back of Dean's Chart about “his name
and the manner of taking poison has
never been reported” refers to the
circumstances of his inoculation- Ames
4
liked to use odd expressions. Dean was
a normal extrovert and taking poison
in the literal sense would never have
occurred to him-

I do not know, or do not recall having
met either Lt. Col. Richman or Col
Oatman at Fort Custer or Col. Floyd
Hunter at Camp Carson, but I
have casually met so many of the
Med. Corps in the days gone by
that I am never sure- I have
not Gen. Ireland's or your memory
for names and faces you know-
I hope you will send me a note
or a postal when you get to your
new station at Camp Carson- It
is always a pleasure to hear from
you- I have returned Ames's indorsement
to your office at Rochester for file, as
I feel sure you do not want to be carrying it around with you.
In your new military life you do not want any impedimenta
which you do not need for military purposes.
